Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: A Role for Microglia in Interhemispheric Remodeling of the Embryonic Forebrain
Award.AbstractNarration:
The cerebral cortex consists of two hemispheres, which are largely distinct structures, but are connected along the midline. This connection is necessary for interhemispheric communication and information integration. The interhemispheric connection is formed and remodeled early during fetal development, but how this occurs is poorly understood. One candidate cell type involved in interhemispheric remodeling is the microglial cell, the immune cell of the brain. Microglia are spatially and temporally correlated with midline development, and known to play a role in remodeling other regions of the cerebral cortex. Understanding interhemispheric remodeling will aid our understanding of communication between the two hemispheres and disorders of the corpus callosum, the structure bridging the two hemispheres. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Linda Richards, one of the world's leading experts on development of the cortical midline, at Queensland Brain Institute in Brisbane, Australia.

Before the two cerebral hemispheres are fused, they are separated by a lining of leptomeningeal fibroblasts. These fibroblasts are removed during midline remodeling, but how they are eliminated is not well understood. To address this question, tissue will be immunostained for markers of leptomeningeal cells, microglial cells, and apoptotic cells. This research follows the hypothesis that microglia are involved in midline remodeling based on their temporospatial correlation and phagocytic nature. The project will assess a role for microglia along the cortical midline through immunohistochemistry by analyzing microglial phagocytosis of leptomeningeal cells, whether phagocytosed cells are apoptotic, and the morphology of phagocytic microglia. This research will provide insight into how the two cerebral hemispheres are fused, a potential novel role for microglia, and could provide an explanation for the distribution of microglia along the cortical midline.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While in Dr. Linda Richards lab at the Queensland Brain Institute I studied whether microglia, the immune cells of the brain, might be involved in how the connection between the two hemispheres of the brain is formed during embryonic development, a process referred to as interhemispheric remodeling. Formation of this connection called the corpus callosum, is critical for communication between the left and right brain hemispheres. Understanding interhemispheric remodeling may provide insight into any of the various disorders of the corpus callosum (which occur in 1:4,000 live births), an area the Richards lab has extensive expertise in. Dr. Richards founded the International Research Consortium for Corpus Callosum and Cerebral Connectivity, a consortium dedicated to understanding abnormal development of the corpus callosum. Additionally, immune dysfunction, which can alter microglial function, has been implicated in a variety of neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism and schizophrenia. Therefore, a role for microglia in interhemispheric remodeling would suggest that this is another process that could be disturbed by immunological insults during embryonic development.

My work suggested that microglia may, indeed, be involved in interhemispheric remodeling. I found an increase in the number of microglia specifically at the site of interhemispheric remodeling during the period of interhemispheric remodeling, as compared to prior to the onset of this process. Moreover, I found that microglia contain fragments of midline cells, suggesting microglia may be phagocytosing, or engulfing, cells of the midline, thereby actively contributing to midline remodeling. My research suggests both a mechanism underlying interhemispheric remodeling, and a novel role for microglia in cortical development. We hope to continue this work in order to further characterize these findings.

While in Australia, I had the opportunity to visit the capital, Canberra, during our orientation and travel throughout the state of Queensland, marveling in its biodiversity. I was very impressed by the Queensland Brain Institute at which I worked- both by the research and its framework. Being in the lab of a strong female scientist was particularly inspiring. I greatly enjoyed the time I spent with people in all walks of life and the warm, unique culture, of this land “down under.”
